required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study to Assess the Pharmacokinetics of a Modified-release Tacrolimus Based Immunosuppression Regimen in Stable Liver Transplant Patients
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 2, Open-Label, Multi-Center Study to Assess the Pharmacokinetics, Long-term Safety and Tolerability of Tacrolimus in Stable Liver Transplant Patients Converted From a Prograf® Based Immunosuppression Regimen to a Modified Release (MR) Tacrolimus Based Immunosuppression Regimen

brief_summary.textblock: A study to assess the pharmacokinetics, safety and effectiveness of tacrolimus in stable liver transplant patients converted from a tacrolimus (Prograf®) based immunosuppression regimen to a modified release tacrolimus based immunosuppression regimen.

detailed_description.textblock: A one arm study to assess the pharmacokinetics, safety and effectiveness of tacrolimus in stable liver transplant patients converted from a tacrolimus (Prograf®) based immunosuppression regimen to a modified release tacrolimus based immunosuppression regimen.

primary_outcome.measure: Area Under the Concentration-time Curve From Time 0 to 24 Hours (AUC0-24) for Tacrolimus
primary_outcome.time_frame: Days 14 and 42 (tacrolimus) and Days 28 and 56 (tacrolimus MR), pre-dose 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12 (pre-dose for tacrolimus only), 12.5, 13, 14, 15, 16, 18, 20, and 24 hours post-dose.
primary_outcome.description: The area under the concentration-time curve was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both the tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR treatment periods at steady state using the linear trapezoidal rule. The AUC0-24 for tacrolimus was calculated as the sum of the AUC0-12 for the morning (0-12 hour) and afternoon (12-24 hour) doses.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Days 14 and 42 at 12 hours post-dose (tacrolimus) and Days 28 and 56 at 24 hours post-dose (for tacrolimus MR).
primary_outcome.description: The trough (minimum) concentration of tacrolimus determined from the tacrolimus whole blood concentration value at the 12 hour post-dose concentration based on the evening dose (i.e., the 8 am concentration) for tacrolimus and the 24-hour time point post-dose for tacrolimus MR, prior to receiving the next dose.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
primary_outcome.description: Patient survival was defined as any participant known to be alive at the time of analysis.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
primary_outcome.description: Graft survival was defined as any participant who did not meet the definition of graft loss, where graft loss was defined as graft failure (re-transplant) or participant death.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Days 14 and 42 (tacrolimus) and Days 28 and 56 (tacrolimus MR), pre-dose, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12 (pre-dose for tacrolimus only), 12.5, 13, 14, 15, 16, 18, 20, and 24 hours post-dose.
secondary_outcome.description: The maximum concentration was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both the tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR treatment periods at steady state, without interpolation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Maximum Observed Concentration of Tacrolimus (Tmax)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Days 14 and 42 (tacrolimus) and Days 28 and 56 (tacrolimus MR), pre-dose, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12 (pre-dose for tacrolimus only), 12.5, 13, 14, 15, 16, 18, 20, and 24 hours post-dose.
secondary_outcome.description: Time to the first occurrence to reach the maximum concentration of tacrolimus was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both the tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR treatment periods at steady state, without interpolation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR) is defined as an episode of acute liver allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ I. Biopsies were graded by the pathologist at the clinical site according to the 1997 Banff criteria for grading of acute liver allograft rejection: Indeterminate: Portal inflammatory infiltrate that fails to meet the criteria for diagnosis of acute rejection; Grade I (Mild): Rejection infiltrate in a minority of the triads that is generally mild and confined within the portal spaces; Grade II (Moderate): Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads; Grade III (Severe): Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads, with spillover into periportal areas and moderate to severe perivenular inflammation that extends into the hepatic parenchyma and is associated with perivenular hepatocyte necrosis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Event for Patient Non-survival
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: For participants who died on study, the median number of days from first dose of study drug to death due to any cause.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Event for Graft Non-survival
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: For participants with graft loss, the median number of days from the first dose of study drug to graft loss. Graft loss was defined as graft failure (re-transplant) or participant death.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to First Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: For participants with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR), the median number of days from the first dose of study drug to the date of biopsy confirmation. BCAR is defined as an episode of acute liver allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ I. Biopsies were graded by the clinical site pathologist according to the 1997 Banff criteria for grading acute liver allograft rejection: Indeterminate: Portal inflammatory infiltrate that fails to meet the criteria for diagnosis of acute rejection; Grade I: Rejection infiltrate in a minority of the triads that is generally mild and confined within the portal spaces; Grade II: Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads; Grade III: Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads, with spillover into periportal areas and moderate to severe perivenular inflammation that extends into the hepatic parenchyma and is associated with perivenular hepatocyte necrosis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Grade of Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection Episodes
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR) is defined as an episode of acute liver allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ I. Biopsies were graded by the clinical site pathologist according to the 1997 Banff criteria for grading of acute liver allograft rejection: Indeterminate: Portal inflammatory infiltrate that fails to meet the criteria for diagnosis of acute rejection; Grade I (Mild): Rejection infiltrate in a minority of the triads that is generally mild and confined within the portal spaces; Grade II (Moderate): Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads; Grade III (Severe): Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads, with spillover into periportal areas and moderate to severe perivenular inflammation that extends into the hepatic parenchyma and is associated with perivenular hepatocyte necrosis. For participants with more than one biopsy-confirmed acute rejection episode, the worst case grade is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Receiving Anti-lymphocyte Antibody Therapy for Acute Rejection
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Steroid-resistant rejection episodes were treated with anti-lymphocyte antibodies. If a participant had a histologically proven Banff Grade II or III rejection, they could be initiated on anti-lymphocyte antibody treatment per institutional practice.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Multiple Rejection Episodes
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: This analysis includes rejection episodes that were either confirmed by biopsy by the clinical site pathologist or were clinically treated.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Clinically Treated Acute Rejection Episodes
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: A clinically treated acute rejection episode was any biopsy-confirmed or suspected rejection episode that was treated with immunosuppressive therapy.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Chronic Rejection
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Due to the low number of participants with biopsy-confirmed acute rejection episodes, chronic rejection was not analyzed.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Treatment Failure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Treatment failure was defined as discontinuation of study drug for any reason. Due to discontinuation of the study by the sponsor, treatment failure was not analyzed.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: The primary reason for graft loss was recorded by the Investigator. Graft loss was defined as graft failure (re-transplant) or participant death.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (the last day of tacrolimus on Day 14 prior to the first conversion to tacrolimus MR), Day 56 (end of the pharmacokinetic phase) and end of treatment (EOT; the last observed value during treatment, maximum time on study was 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Hepatic function was assessed by measuring alanine aminotransferase levels over the course of the study.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (the last day of tacrolimus on Day 14 prior to the first conversion to tacrolimus MR), Day 56 (end of the pharmacokinetic phase) and end of treatment (EOT; the last observed value during treatment, maximum time on study was 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Hepatic function was assessed by measuring aspartate aminotransferase levels over the course of the study.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Total Bilirubin
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (the last day of tacrolimus on Day 14 prior to the first conversion to tacrolimus MR), Day 56 (end of the pharmacokinetic phase) and end of treatment (EOT; the last observed value during treatment, maximum time on study was 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: Hepatic function was assessed by measuring total bilirubin over the course of the study.

secondary_outcome.measure: Safety as Assessed by Adverse Events, Laboratory Parameters and Vital Signs
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From the first dose of tacrolimus MR formulation through the last dose day plus 10 days (approximately 60 months).
secondary_outcome.description: An adverse event is defined as any reaction, side effect or other untoward medical occurrence, regardless of the relationship to study drug which occurred during the conduct of a clinical study. Clinically significant adverse changes in clinical status, routine laboratory studies or physical examinations were considered adverse events. A serious adverse event was any adverse event occurring at any dose that resulted in any of the following outcomes: Death Life-threatening adverse event Inpatient hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization Persistent or significant disability or incapacity Congenital abnormality or birth defect Important medical event.

arm_group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient is currently receiving Prograf ® based immunosuppressive therapy for liver transplantation.
- Patient has stable whole blood trough level concentrations of Prograf® and is clinically stable
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient has previously received an organ transplant other than a liver
- Patient is currently receiving sirolimus immunosuppression therapy.

reference.citation: Florman S, Alloway R, Kalayoglu M, Punch J, Bak T, Melancon J, Klintmalm G, Busque S, Charlton M, Lake J, Dhadda S, Wisemandle K, Wirth M, Fitzsimmons W, Holman J, First MR. Once-daily tacrolimus extended release formulation: experience at 2 years postconversion from a Prograf-based regimen in stable liver transplant recipients. Transplantation. 2007 Jun 27;83(12):1639-42.

Florman S, Alloway R, Kalayoglu M, Lake K, Bak T, Klein A, Klintmalm G, Busque S, Brandenhagen D, Lake J, Wisemandle K, Fitzsimmons W, First MR. Conversion of stable liver transplant recipients from a twice-daily Prograf-based regimen to a once-daily modified release tacrolimus-based regimen. Transplant Proc. 2005 Mar;37(2):1211-3.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Stable liver transplant recipients aged 18 to 65 years who were on a stable dose of tacrolimus based immunosuppressive regimen.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Pharmacokinetic (PK) treatment period was 56 days. Participants who completed the PK period were eligible to continue receiving tacrolimus MR in the extended treatment period, from Day 57 up to 60 months.

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

baseline.population: Pharmacokinetic evaluable set, defined as all patients with four complete pharmacokinetic profiles (two tacrolimus and two tacrolimus MR).

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Age
Gender
Race/Ethnicity, Customized
Reason for End Stage Liver Disease
Type of Current Transplant
Re-transplant

outcome.title: Area Under the Concentration-time Curve From Time 0 to 24 Hours (AUC0-24) for Tacrolimus
outcome.description: The area under the concentration-time curve was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both the tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR treatment periods at steady state using the linear trapezoidal rule. The AUC0-24 for tacrolimus was calculated as the sum of the AUC0-12 for the morning (0-12 hour) and afternoon (12-24 hour) doses.
outcome.time_frame: Days 14 and 42 (tacrolimus) and Days 28 and 56 (tacrolimus MR), pre-dose 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12 (pre-dose for tacrolimus only), 12.5, 13, 14, 15, 16, 18, 20, and 24 hours post-dose.
outcome.population: Pharmacokinetic evaluable set defined as all patients with four complete pharmacokinetic profiles (two tacrolimus and 2 tacrolimus MR).

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Area Under the Concentration-time Curve From Time 0 to 24 Hours (AUC0-24) for Tacrolimus
measure.description: The area under the concentration-time curve was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both the tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR treatment periods at steady state using the linear trapezoidal rule. The AUC0-24 for tacrolimus was calculated as the sum of the AUC0-12 for the morning (0-12 hour) and afternoon (12-24 hour) doses.
measure.population: Pharmacokinetic evaluable set defined as all patients with four complete pharmacokinetic profiles (two tacrolimus and 2 tacrolimus MR).

analysis.groups_desc: The method of analysis of variance with repeated measures was used for the comparisons of AUC0-24. Exposure at steady state was used for tacrolimus (steady state was defined as days 14 and 42) and for tacrolimus MR (steady state was defined as days 28 and 56). The natural log (ln) was used to transform AUC0-24 prior to analysis and the results were transformed back to the original scale for the presentation of results.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: If the 90% CI for the ratio of the natural log-transformed pharmacokinetic parameters fell within an 80% to 125% range, then the exposure between the two formulations was considered to be equivalent.
analysis.estimate_desc: Tacrolimus/tacrolimus MR ratio of natural log transformed means expressed as a percent.

outcome.title: Maximum Observed Concentration of Tacrolimus (Cmax)
outcome.description: The maximum concentration was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both the tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR treatment periods at steady state, without interpolation.
outcome.time_frame: Days 14 and 42 (tacrolimus) and Days 28 and 56 (tacrolimus MR), pre-dose, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12 (pre-dose for tacrolimus only), 12.5, 13, 14, 15, 16, 18, 20, and 24 hours post-dose.

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Maximum Observed Concentration of Tacrolimus (Cmax)
measure.description: The maximum concentration was calculated from whole blood tacrolimus concentrations for both the tacrolimus and tacrolimus MR treatment periods at steady state, without interpolation.

outcome.title: Minimum Observed Concentration of Tacrolimus (Cmin)
outcome.description: The trough (minimum) concentration of tacrolimus determined from the tacrolimus whole blood concentration value at the 12 hour post-dose concentration based on the evening dose (i.e., the 8 am concentration) for tacrolimus and the 24-hour time point post-dose for tacrolimus MR, prior to receiving the next dose.
outcome.time_frame: Days 14 and 42 at 12 hours post-dose (tacrolimus) and Days 28 and 56 at 24 hours post-dose (for tacrolimus MR).

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Minimum Observed Concentration of Tacrolimus (Cmin)
measure.description: The trough (minimum) concentration of tacrolimus determined from the tacrolimus whole blood concentration value at the 12 hour post-dose concentration based on the evening dose (i.e., the 8 am concentration) for tacrolimus and the 24-hour time point post-dose for tacrolimus MR, prior to receiving the next dose.

analysis.groups_desc: The method of analysis of variance with repeated measures was used for the comparisons of Cmin. Exposure at steady state was used for tacrolimus (steady state was defined as days 14 and 42) and for tacrolimus MR (steady state was defined as days 28 and 56). The natural log (ln) was used to transform Cmin prior to analysis and the results were transformed back to the original scale for the presentation of results.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: If the 90% CI for the ratio of the natural log-transformed pharmacokinetic parameters fell within an 80% to 125% range, then the exposure between the two formulations was considered to be equivalent.
analysis.estimate_desc: Tacrolimus/tacrolimus MR ratio of natural log transformed means expressed as a percent.

outcome.title: Patient Survival
outcome.description: Patient survival was defined as any participant known to be alive at the time of analysis.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
outcome.population: Modified full analysis set, defined as all patients who took at least one dose of tacrolimus MR during the extended treatment period of the study.

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Patient Survival
measure.description: Patient survival was defined as any participant known to be alive at the time of analysis.
measure.population: Modified full analysis set, defined as all patients who took at least one dose of tacrolimus MR during the extended treatment period of the study.

outcome.title: Graft Survival
outcome.description: Graft survival was defined as any participant who did not meet the definition of graft loss, where graft loss was defined as graft failure (re-transplant) or participant death.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).

outcome.description: For participants who died on study, the median number of days from first dose of study drug to death due to any cause.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
outcome.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set who died on study.

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. outcome.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with graft loss.

outcome.description: For participants with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR), the median number of days from the first dose of study drug to the date of biopsy confirmation. BCAR is defined as an episode of acute liver allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ I. Biopsies were graded by the clinical site pathologist according to the 1997 Banff criteria for grading acute liver allograft rejection: Indeterminate: Portal inflammatory infiltrate that fails to meet the criteria for diagnosis of acute rejection; Grade I: Rejection infiltrate in a minority of the triads that is generally mild and confined within the portal spaces; Grade II: Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads; Grade III: Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads, with spillover into periportal areas and moderate to severe perivenular inflammation that extends into the hepatic parenchyma and is associated with perivenular hepatocyte necrosis.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
outcome.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection.

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Time to First Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection
measure.description: For participants with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR), the median number of days from the first dose of study drug to the date of biopsy confirmation. BCAR is defined as an episode of acute liver allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ I. Biopsies were graded by the clinical site pathologist according to the 1997 Banff criteria for grading acute liver allograft rejection: Indeterminate: Portal inflammatory infiltrate that fails to meet the criteria for diagnosis of acute rejection; Grade I: Rejection infiltrate in a minority of the triads that is generally mild and confined within the portal spaces; Grade II: Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads; Grade III: Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads, with spillover into periportal areas and moderate to severe perivenular inflammation that extends into the hepatic parenchyma and is associated with perivenular hepatocyte necrosis.
measure.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection.

outcome.title: Grade of Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection Episodes
outcome.description: Biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR) is defined as an episode of acute liver allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ I. Biopsies were graded by the clinical site pathologist according to the 1997 Banff criteria for grading of acute liver allograft rejection: Indeterminate: Portal inflammatory infiltrate that fails to meet the criteria for diagnosis of acute rejection; Grade I (Mild): Rejection infiltrate in a minority of the triads that is generally mild and confined within the portal spaces; Grade II (Moderate): Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads; Grade III (Severe): Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads, with spillover into periportal areas and moderate to severe perivenular inflammation that extends into the hepatic parenchyma and is associated with perivenular hepatocyte necrosis. For participants with more than one biopsy-confirmed acute rejection episode, the worst case grade is reported.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
outcome.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection.

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Grade of Biopsy-confirmed Acute Rejection Episodes
measure.description: Biopsy-confirmed acute rejection (BCAR) is defined as an episode of acute liver allograft rejection that was confirmed by biopsy results and was Banff grade ≥ I. Biopsies were graded by the clinical site pathologist according to the 1997 Banff criteria for grading of acute liver allograft rejection: Indeterminate: Portal inflammatory infiltrate that fails to meet the criteria for diagnosis of acute rejection; Grade I (Mild): Rejection infiltrate in a minority of the triads that is generally mild and confined within the portal spaces; Grade II (Moderate): Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads; Grade III (Severe): Rejection infiltrate, expanding to most or all of the triads, with spillover into periportal areas and moderate to severe perivenular inflammation that extends into the hepatic parenchyma and is associated with perivenular hepatocyte necrosis. For participants with more than one biopsy-confirmed acute rejection episode, the worst case grade is reported.
measure.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with a biopsy-confirmed acute rejection.

outcome.title: Number of Participants Receiving Anti-lymphocyte Antibody Therapy for Acute Rejection
outcome.description: Steroid-resistant rejection episodes were treated with anti-lymphocyte antibodies. If a participant had a histologically proven Banff Grade II or III rejection, they could be initiated on anti-lymphocyte antibody treatment per institutional practice.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Number of Participants Receiving Anti-lymphocyte Antibody Therapy for Acute Rejection
measure.description: Steroid-resistant rejection episodes were treated with anti-lymphocyte antibodies. If a participant had a histologically proven Banff Grade II or III rejection, they could be initiated on anti-lymphocyte antibody treatment per institutional practice.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Multiple Rejection Episodes
outcome.description: This analysis includes rejection episodes that were either confirmed by biopsy by the clinical site pathologist or were clinically treated.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Number of Participants With Multiple Rejection Episodes
measure.description: This analysis includes rejection episodes that were either confirmed by biopsy by the clinical site pathologist or were clinically treated.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Clinically Treated Acute Rejection Episodes
outcome.description: A clinically treated acute rejection episode was any biopsy-confirmed or suspected rejection episode that was treated with immunosuppressive therapy.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Number of Participants With Clinically Treated Acute Rejection Episodes
measure.description: A clinically treated acute rejection episode was any biopsy-confirmed or suspected rejection episode that was treated with immunosuppressive therapy.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Chronic Rejection
outcome.description: Due to the low number of participants with biopsy-confirmed acute rejection episodes, chronic rejection was not analyzed.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Number of Participants With Chronic Rejection
measure.description: Due to the low number of participants with biopsy-confirmed acute rejection episodes, chronic rejection was not analyzed.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Treatment Failure
outcome.description: Treatment failure was defined as discontinuation of study drug for any reason. Due to discontinuation of the study by the sponsor, treatment failure was not analyzed.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Number of Participants With Treatment Failure
measure.description: Treatment failure was defined as discontinuation of study drug for any reason. Due to discontinuation of the study by the sponsor, treatment failure was not analyzed.

outcome.title: Primary Reason for Graft Loss
outcome.description: The primary reason for graft loss was recorded by the Investigator. Graft loss was defined as graft failure (re-transplant) or participant death.
outcome.time_frame: From enrollment until the end of study (up to 60 months).
outcome.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with graft loss.

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Primary Reason for Graft Loss
measure.description: The primary reason for graft loss was recorded by the Investigator. Graft loss was defined as graft failure (re-transplant) or participant death.
measure.population: Participants in the modified full analysis set with graft loss.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT)
outcome.description: Hepatic function was assessed by measuring alanine aminotransferase levels over the course of the study.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline (the last day of tacrolimus on Day 14 prior to the first conversion to tacrolimus MR), Day 56 (end of the pharmacokinetic phase) and end of treatment (EOT; the last observed value during treatment, maximum time on study was 60 months).
outcome.population: Modified safety analysis set defined as all patients who took at least 1 dose of tacrolimus and at least one dose of tacrolimus MR during the pharmacokinetic portion of the study. "N" indicates the number of participants with available data at each time point.

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

outcome.title: Safety as Assessed by Adverse Events, Laboratory Parameters and Vital Signs
outcome.description: An adverse event is defined as any reaction, side effect or other untoward medical occurrence, regardless of the relationship to study drug which occurred during the conduct of a clinical study. Clinically significant adverse changes in clinical status, routine laboratory studies or physical examinations were considered adverse events. A serious adverse event was any adverse event occurring at any dose that resulted in any of the following outcomes: Death Life-threatening adverse event Inpatient hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization Persistent or significant disability or incapacity Congenital abnormality or birth defect Important medical event.
outcome.time_frame: From the first dose of tacrolimus MR formulation through the last dose day plus 10 days (approximately 60 months).

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

measure.title: Safety as Assessed by Adverse Events, Laboratory Parameters and Vital Signs
measure.description: An adverse event is defined as any reaction, side effect or other untoward medical occurrence, regardless of the relationship to study drug which occurred during the conduct of a clinical study. Clinically significant adverse changes in clinical status, routine laboratory studies or physical examinations were considered adverse events. A serious adverse event was any adverse event occurring at any dose that resulted in any of the following outcomes: Death Life-threatening adverse event Inpatient hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization Persistent or significant disability or incapacity Congenital abnormality or birth defect Important medical event.

class.title: Adverse event leading to dose changes

reported_events.time_frame: From the first dose of tacrolimus MR formulation through the last dose day plus 10 days (approximately 60 months).
reported_events.desc: Adverse events are reported for the modified safety analysis set defined as all patients who took at least 1 dose of tacrolimus and one dose of tacrolimus MR during the pharmacokinetic period of the study.

group.title: Tacrolimus MR
group.description: After enrollment in the pharmacokinetic period, patients were maintained on their usual dose of tacrolimus twice daily on Day 1 through Day 14 and on Day 15 were converted to tacrolimus modified release (MR) once-daily in the morning for 14 days, converted back to tacrolimus twice daily for 14 days and then converted back to tacrolimus MR formulation once-daily in the morning for 14 days, all based on a 1:1 mg for mg total daily dose conversion. The extended treatment period began on day 57 and consisted of a single dose of tacrolimus extended-release formulation once every morning through the end of the study. Dose adjustments were allowed in order to maintain the target tacrolimus trough level within the range of 5 to 20 ng/mL and for clinical reasons.

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Institute and/or Principal Investigator may publish trial data generated at their specific study site after Sponsor publication of the multi-center data or until 18 months have elapsed following study completion. Sponsor must receive a site’s manuscript at least 30 days prior to publication to ensure that no confidential information of Sponsor is included in the document.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Vice President, Therapeutic Area Head, Transplantation
